title: TIL THERE'S NO WIND
description: This photo series can best be described as the diary of a special roadtrip. The starting point was a small town two hours North of Albuquerque, New Mexico, and the destination, a secluded campus in the middle of the Sierra Nevada desert, California. The participants were me, a Vietnamese photographer who had just barely arrived to the United States; T, a friend I had met in an international high school; and Fat Boy, a pit bull that T adopted the day before departure. When T got suspended half way through our high school program, he invited me to visit his home in New Mexico if I ever had the chance to. Three years later, I found myself celebrating Christmas with T in a small section-eight apartment, where his childhood friend and a hitchhiker from Kentucky were also crashing. The trip that I planned for T and I would take us to someone we both knew from high school. However, things went unexpectedly as I had kept T’s arrival a secret.

Every shot in this series is contained within a one-month period in which the captured events took place. Thus, time plays an important role, as it is the main factor driving the narrative forward. By providing the viewer with this information and the background above, I hope to create a feeling of urgency that is less common in long-term photo projects. Specifically, there is a sense of constant arrival and departure against the backdrop of the American West that cannot be stopped because they had already happened—and in fact, been photographed. The captions, many of which were written in future tense, also play an important role. Firstly, they break the constraint imposed on the story by the time dimensionality; and secondly, they encourage the viewers to imagine what happened, or will happen, beyond the observations of the camera. Some imperfections from handling and processing the film, while unintentional, worked really well in provoking the affect of the trip—rough, hasty, and often unpredictable. Therefore, wherever relevant, I kept them for the purpose of heightening emotions that some exposures may provoke.

I have tried various ways to contextualize this series, but they seem more like pieces of an incomplete puzzle rather than a nicely painted picture. Such contextualization also risks belittling the subjects in the series—real yet fragile, troubled yet charismatic people whose life go on independent from the black and white snapshots that captured but a small part of their complexities. It is perhaps best that I only provide the backbone of the narrative, and let viewers do the contextualization themselves. Regardless, during these fleeting encounters, I will say that there was a sentiment that I sensed in most subjects, including myself: the desire to seek stillness within changing conditions one did not choose. More often than not, this desire will fall short of itself. I decided to name the series after a remark that T once made: “I don’t mind the clouds as long as it’s not windy. I don’t mind the snow as long as it’s not windy. I don’t mind the cold as long as it’s not windy.”
captions: T’s section-8 one-bedroom apartment. Living room.
C, T’s childhood friend, had been staying with him after a family argument. He was the only one in the house old enough to buy alcohol. In 3 weeks, C and T will get into a big fight.

S liked talking about his direct experience with God after taking psychedelics. He was hitchhiking from Kentucky to California and back when T’s father picked him up in Albuquerque. His friends nicknamed him “Messi”, short for “Messiah”.
T’s recently adopted cat. He named it “Muc”, meaning ink in Vietnamese. In a year, Muc will run away and couldn’t be found.
T playing his guitar. He refused to go on the road trip without it.
T’s 2001 manual Nissan, a pass-down from his dad. In 2 years, this Nissan will lose a race against a Chevy Camaro before being towed by the police. It has not been recovered since.

Messi in a natural hot spring tub. 9 months ago, he hit the road after an argument with his girlfriend. Since then, he'd been collecting souvernirs for his girlfriend's daughter, who he considered his own.
Moments after T'd cooled off from a dip, a passerby shouted 'Put some clothes on'. T often goes to the hot spring when he feels low.
T on his dad: 'He'd go out for a pack of cigarettes and be gone for a year.'
T and his dad after checking on the Nissan together. It was deemed unfit for the upcoming trip.
T's childhood friend, C, offered him his car. It was a manual Subaru WRX that C had saved up for over many years.
T took the Subaru to a mechanic who was a friend of his dad. It was in dire need of fresh tires and an oil change.
The mechanic lived on a ranch with a pack of dogs. There, T met and adopted a pitbull. It's been named been named “Fat Boy” by its previous owner, who recently got sentenced to jail.
T with Fat Boy and C's car.
'It’s time to go home', Messi said. None of us have heard from him since.
A cemetery on the outskirts of T’s hometown.
By sunset, the car made it to Taos. Its battery died and there wont' be help until the next morning.
Entering Colorado. I saw snow for the first time.
T walking Fat Boy outside of a gas station.
Entering Utah. The camera got jammed.
Waiting out a storm in Salt Lake City.
Fat Boy standing before a frozen lake, Nevada.
Setting up camp.
Entering the Sierra Nevada.
Fat Boy running freely on a backroad. In 12 hours, the car battery will die again.
A retired LAPD officer jumped the car. A year ago, his pitbull died and was buried nearby. “I got a gun”, he warned when T first approached. He only let his guard down after seeing Fat Boy.
Fat Boy taking a nap. In 6 months, he will have a new owner.
Deep Springs Valley, California. The destination.
K, who we had driven all the way to meet, took us to a natural hot spring.
T’s arrival came as a big surprise to K. They used to live in the same dorm in high school.
T had a reputation.
The following day, we went on a day trip.
Death Valley, California.
An argument broke out. T decided to leave.
We bid farewell. In a week, T will be locked outside of the Subaru on his way home. He will have to break the window to get in.
K standing on the dumpsite of his college. Less than 20 students were enrolled at any given point.
K and I got Covid and was quarantined in a spare cottage. Ten minutes earlier, someone had left a half-empty bottle of whiskey on the porch.
K was a Czech photojournalist who had recently returned from Ukraine. Out of boredom, he suggested going on a hike.
The Druid, Deep Springs Valley, California.
K overlooking the Deep Springs valley. In less than a year, K will drop out and go to Ukraine again.
K took a photo of me. Two years later, the frame will be developed in a public bathroom at a college on the East coast.
End of roll.
